title: La Tomatina: Party-goers hurl tonnes of tomatoes in Spanish festival

The annual Tomatina festival was held on August 26, 2015 in Bunol, Spain. 
An estimated 22,000 people showed up. 
Around 150 tonnes of ripe tomatoes were thrown. 
It's known as the world's biggest tomato fight. 
The festival takes place in the Spanish town of Buñol. 
The tomatoes were brought in on seven trucks for the battle that lasted about an hour. 
The festival started in 1945.... 
.... when local children got into a food fight. 
The following year, the fight was deliberately repeated and has since become an annual tradition. 
The entire town is painted red as tomato juice flows freely through the streets. 
When an hour is up, a shot is fired to announce the end of the festival. 
The town's streets and walls are hosed down once the battle ends. 
The village is actually known to be cleaner after the festival as the acidity in the tomatoes disinfects the streets. 
Portable showers were set up so revellers could shower afterwards. 
The event, banned for a time during the 1950s at the height of General Francisco Franco's dictatorship, has drawn a huge international following in recent years. 
"It's crazy, like a massive orgy of tomatoes and people," said Evaran James, a 30-year-old from Australia. 1 of 16 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
Tens of thousands of festival-goers hurled 170 tonnes of over-ripe tomatoes at each other on Wednesday to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the massive food fight in the small town of Bunol in eastern Spain. 
Spaniards and tourists from around the world, some wearing goggles to protect their eyes from the flying fruit, crammed the narrow streets to smear each other with seven truckloads of squashed tomatoes. 
"It's crazy, like a massive orgy of tomatoes and people," said Evaran James, a 30-year-old from Australia. DAVID RAMOS/GETTY IMAGES 
Revellers enjoy the atmosphere in tomato pulp while participating in the annual Tomatina festival in Bunol, Spain 
Houses and shops draped covers over their facades to protect them from the red juice and pulp. 
The 'Tomatina' fight originates from a spontaneous bust-up amongst villagers in 1945. The event, banned for a time during the 1950s at the height of General Francisco Franco's dictatorship, has drawn a huge international following in recent years.
